stem: The public health nurse is conducting a community seminar on liver health. Based on the documentation in the Social & Occupational History for four individuals, match each risk profile with the correct prevention and teaching priority.

tabs.title: Nurses' Notes
tabs.content:
Patient A: 19y/o male planning a trip to a rural area with limited access to clean water. 
Patient B: 42y/o female healthcare worker in a dialysis unit; has multiple needle-stick risks. 
Patient C: 25y/o male with history of intravenous drug use; shares equipment. 
Patient D: 32y/o female preparing food in a local restaurant that recently had a sewage leak.

tabs.title: Social & Occupational History
tabs.content:
PatientPrimary Risk AreaEducation Goal
ATravel to endemic fecal-oral regionFood/Water safety
BBlood-borne exposurePPE Compliance
CShared needlesHarm reduction
DFecal-contaminated food sourceHand hygiene

tabs.title: Immunity Status
tabs.content:
Patient B: Anti-HBs Positive (Immune). 
Patient C: Anti-HCV Negative (Susceptible).

rows.text: Drinking only bottled water and eating cooked foods
Using condoms and avoiding the sharing of razors/needles
Receiving a 2-dose vaccine series at 0 and 6 months
Receiving a 3-dose vaccine series at 0, 1, and 6 months

rationale.correct: Hepatitis A is fecal-oral, so prevention focuses on hand hygiene and food/water safety (r1); its vaccine is a 2-dose series (r3). Hepatitis B & C are blood-borne, so prevention focuses on avoiding shared needles/fluids (r2). The Hep B vaccine is a 3-dose series (r4).
clinicalPearls: Hep A and E: Vowels (A/E) come from the Bowel.
Hep B and C: B for Blood/Body fluids.
There is NO vaccine for Hep C.

questionTrap.trap: Thinking Hep C has a 3-dose vaccine like Hep B.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Only Hep A and Hep B have FDA-approved vaccines. C has no preventative vaccine.
